title: Q and Z - hybridization- IMFs- H2CrO4 mechanism

content.question: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student investigates the physical and chemical properties of various carbon-containing compounds. The complete Lewis electron-dot diagrams and boiling points for two compounds, <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, are shown in the following table. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of the carbon atom in compound <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is indicated by the arrow in the diagram.

frqParts.text: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student investigates the physical and chemical properties of various carbon-containing compounds. The complete Lewis electron-dot diagrams and boiling points for two compounds, <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, are shown in the following table. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of the carbon atom in compound <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is indicated by the arrow in the diagram.

(b) Any <math alttext="C H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond in compound <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shorter than the <math alttext="S H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond in compound <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain the reason for this difference using principles of atomic structure.

(c) For each compound, list all intermolecular forces present. Compound <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> – Compound <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> –

(d) Explain why the boiling point of compound <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is higher than that of compound <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> based on the types and relative strengths of the intermolecular forces present in each substance.

(e) A gaseous sample of compound <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed in an evacuated <math alttext="4.0 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.0</mn><mtext> L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cylinder with a movable piston. If the initial pressure in the cylinder is <math alttext="0.60 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.60</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, determine the new pressure when the volume is increased to <math alttext="10.0 liters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mtext> L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at constant temperature.

Another carbon-containing compound is <math alttext="C 2 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which reacts with <math alttext="H 2 C r O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the following equation. <math alttext="C 2 H 6 O plus H 2 C r O 4 react to produce C 2 H 4 O plus H 2 C r O 3 plus H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O +</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O +</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (f) The student claims that <math alttext="C r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is oxidized when <math alttext="H 2 C r O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is converted to <math alttext="H 2 C r O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

The reaction is known to be exothermic. A proposed mechanism for the reaction is shown in the following table. Step 1 <math alttext="C 2 H 6 O plus H 2 C r O 4 is in equilibrium with C 2 H 5 C r O 4 H plus H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O +</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext> H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>H +</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext> H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> fast Step 2 ​<math alttext="C 2 H 5 C r O 4 H reacts to produce C 2 H 4 O plus H 2 C r O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>H</mtext><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O +</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext> H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> slow (g) The student draws the following energy diagram for the reaction. Is the drawing consistent with the proposed mechanism? Justify your answer.

(h) The reaction is run in an excess of <math alttext="H 2 C r O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> such that <math alttext="the molar concentration of H 2 C r O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cr</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> remains constant. The student claims that under these conditions, the reaction is first-order with respect to <math alttext="C 2 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and that the rate constant of the reaction is <math alttext="0.20 min raised to the power of negative one" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>min</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the following graph consistent with the student’s claim? Justify your answer with respect to the graph’s axes and the numerical value of the slope of the line.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
